title: Philly Cheesesteak Recipe
description: This Philly cheesesteak has perfectly tender sliced steak and caramelized onions in a roll topped with melted cheese to make the ultimate sandwich.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Main Dishes Sandwich Recipes Beef Philly Cheesesteak 4.6 (451) 335 Reviews 49 Photos This Philly cheesesteak is made with sirloin sliced into strips and seasoned with a delicious blend of herbs and spices for a flavorsome sandwich. Sometimes I toast the hoagie roll before topping it with the steak, caramelized onions, peppers, and cheese. Submitted by SWIZZLESTICKS Updated on July 25, 2024 Save Rate Print Share Add Photo 49 49 49 49 Prep Time: 15 mins Cook Time: 25 mins Total Time: 40 mins Servings: 4 Yield: 4 cheesesteaks Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 4 servings ½ teaspoon salt ½ teaspoon black pepper ½ teaspoon paprika ½ teaspoon chili powder ½ teaspoon onion powder ½ teaspoon garlic powder ½ teaspoon dried thyme ½ teaspoon dried marjoram ½ teaspoon dried basil 1 pound beef sirloin, cut into thin 2 inch strips 3 tablespoons vegetable oil 1 onion, sliced 1 green bell pepper, julienned 3 ounces Swiss cheese, thinly sliced 4 hoagie rolls, split lengthwise Directions Gather all ingredients. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Mix salt, pepper, paprika, chili powder, onion powder, garlic powder, thyme, marjoram, and basil together in a small bowl. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Place steak in a large bowl; sprinkle seasoning mixture over top and stir to coat. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Heat 1/2 of the oil in a skillet over medium-high heat. Add steak; cook and stir to the desired doneness. Transfer cooked steak to a plate. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Heat the remaining oil in the skillet. Add onion and green pepper; cook and stir until tender and caramelized. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Preheat the oven on the broiler setting. Divide cooked beef between the bottoms of 4 rolls. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Layer with onion and green pepper. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Top with sliced cheese. Place on a cookie sheet. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Broil in the preheated oven until cheese is melted. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Cover with tops of rolls and serve. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios I Made It Print 580 home cooks made it! Nutrition Facts (per serving) 641 Calories 38g Fat 40g Carbs 35g Protein Show Full Nutrition Label Hide Full Nutrition Label Nutrition Facts Servings Per Recipe 4 Calories 641 % Daily Value * Total Fat 38g 49% Saturated Fat 14g 69% Cholesterol 96mg 32% Sodium 717mg 31% Total Carbohydrate 40g 14% Dietary Fiber 3g 12% Total Sugars 6g Protein 35g 71% Vitamin C 26mg 29% Calcium 277mg 21% Iron 5mg 27% Potassium 500mg 11% * Percent Daily Values are based on a 2,000 calorie diet. Your daily values may be higher or lower depending on your calorie needs. ** Nutrient information is not available for all ingredients. Amount is based on available nutrient data. (-) Information is not currently available for this nutrient. If you are following a medically restrictive diet, please consult your doctor or registered dietitian before preparing this recipe for personal consumption. Add Your Photo Photos of Philly Cheesesteak 01 of 49 Photo by  Dotdash Meredith Food Studios 02 of 49 Photo by  cstakely 02/14/2025 Upon first bite my husband said it was the best steak sandwich he’s ever had so that was a good start. I made according to recipe as I like to see how the ‘original’ tastes before I start tweaking but I couldn’t resist adding some mozzarella cheese along with the Swiss. I’m a lightweight when it comes to spicy so I may cut back a little on the pepper and chili powder. I thought it was easy to follow, easy to prepare, and easy to eat! Will be making again! 03 of 49 Photo by  Victoria Harvis 11/16/2023 04 of 49 Photo by  RavenWolf 03/06/2023 I used all the seasonings on the recipe,but the veggies I used green peppers,white onion, and a red onion. Instead of chez whiz and provolone, I used swiss and mozzarella cheese sticks and diced them up and added to the steak, onions and peppers. And for us budget minded and rib eye steak is not an option. I used flank steak cut into strips,mixed the seasonings in and let sit in fridge to tenderize the meat. Came out really good. I also used hamburger buns to cut carbs. 05 of 49 Photo by  Danielle Goodman 12/01/2022 This was great! I did sub the Swiss cheese for provolone however, and I sautéd my veggies 1st then added the meat to sauté together. I also used the really thin steak that’s purposed to make cheese steaks. My husband raved about it!😉 06 of 49 Photo by  Anthony Ritter 07/03/2021 07 of 49 Photo by  Blaze 03/29/2021 08 of 49 Photo by  Elaine O'Byrne 03/14/2021 09 of 49 Photo by  dknight0909 10/11/2020 10 of 49 Photo by  Souheir 09/07/2020 I used T-bone steak for the beef. I also added a tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce to the beef and veggie mix. This turned out real good. I used olive oil instead of vegetable oil. The food was on point and not fatty grease. 1 2 3 4 5 Next You’ll Also Love Slow Cooker Philly Steak Sandwich Meat 112 Ratings Griddle-Style Philly Steak Sandwiches Recipe 114 Ratings Philly Cheesesteak Sliders 32 Ratings Reuben Sandwich 724 Ratings Philly Cheesesteak Sandwich with Garlic Mayo 1,073 Ratings E-A-G-L-E-S Swirl Sandwich 51 Ratings Baked Philly Cheesesteak Sliders 16 Ratings Philly Cheese Steak 40 Ratings Pittsburgh Sandwich 21 Ratings Mini Philly Cheesesteaks 52 Ratings Chef John's Beef on Weck Sandwiches 20 Ratings Beef on Weck 29 Ratings Mary Pat's Tuna Melt 14 Ratings Philly Cheese Steak Sliders 13 Ratings Ting-Town Barbeque Beef Sandwich 42 Ratings Philly Cheese Steak Sloppy Joes 15 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family.
